H0.text: Other stars are farther from Earth than the Sun is the best explanation for why stars seen in the night sky are less bright than the Sun.

H1.text: Other stars are facing away from Earth, which explains why stars seen in the night sky are less bright than the Sun.

H2.text: Other stars are smaller than the Sun, which explains why stars seen in the night sky are less bright than the Sun.

H3.text: Other stars are producing less light explains why stars seen in the night sky are less bright than the Sun.

A6.text: The intensity (or illuminance or irradiance) of light or other linear waves radiating from a point source (energy per unit of area perpendicular to the source) is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source, so an object (of the same size) twice as far away receives only one-quarter the energy (in the same time period).
